citation.article-title: Characterization of the marine propionate-degrading, sulfate-reducing bacterium Desulfofaba fastidiosa sp. nov. and reclassification of Desulfomusa hansenii as Desulfofaba hansenii comb. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Desulfofaba fastidiosa sp. nov.
Desulfofaba fastidiosa (fas.ti.di.o′sa. L. fem. adj. fastidiosa fastidious, difficult to please, referring to the limited number of substrates used by the type strain).
Cells are curved, bean-shaped rods, 3–3·8 μm long and 0·8–1·0 μm wide when grown with sulfate, but longer when grown with thiosulfate.
Cells are motile and have a single polar flagellum.
Anaerobic growth with propionate, lactate or 1-propanol as electron donors and sulfate, sulfite or thiosulfate as electron acceptors.
Growth is also possible by fermentation of lactate.
The pH range for growth is 6·0–7·75 (optimum 6·8–7·1).
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 48·8 mol%.
The type strain, P2T (=DSM 15249T=ATCC BAA-815T), was isolated from the sulfate–methane transition zone (1·5 m below sediment surface) of Aarhus Bay (Denmark).
